summary:
=== Purchase Information === Review Date: 2013/09/01 Average Rating: 4.4 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Nudity', 'violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Martin McDonagh'], 'Producers': ['Graham Broadbent', 'Peter Czernin', 'Martin McDonagh'], 'Starring': ['Colin Farrell', 'Sam Rockwell', 'Woody Harrelson'], 'Studio': ['Paramount']} Review Text: I trusted the trailer that this was going to be a quirky comedy about a dog napper who took the wrong dog. It wasn't. It's violent without any point. I see 4 and 5 star reviews that are trying to point out sophisticated meanings, but really, this was just an excuse to put stupid stuff and gore on the screen. Kept watching because the cast was good, they did a terrific job. Save your money and find another movie. Review Title: Not a comedy about a dog napper Rating: 1.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Review Date: 2014/07/15 Average Rating: 4.7 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English Dialogue Boost: High', 'English', 'English [Audio Description]', 'English Dialogue Boost: Medium'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Stuart Dryburgh', 'Ben Stiller'], 'Producers': ['Ben Stiller', 'G. Mac Brown', 'Stuart Cornfeld', 'Samuel Goldwyn Jr.', 'John Goldwyn', 'Meyer Gottlieb', 'Matt Levin', 'Jeff Mann', 'Ethan Shapanka', 'Gore Verbinski'], 'Starring': ['Ben Stiller', 'Kristen Wiig', 'Shirley MacLaine'], 'Studio': ['Epix']} Review Text: Well done! Loved the ending. Review Title: You gotta watch this movie. Rating: 5.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Review Date: 2014/09/11 Average Rating: 4.6 Product Details: {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Suzan Beraza'], 'Producers': ['Suzan Beraza'], 'Starring': ['Jeb Berrier', 'Jared Blumenfeld', 'Martin Bourque']} Review Text: My son told me about this and asked me to watch it, I did, and the last few days since watching this documentary can only be described as conscious. When I put something away in the fridge, I try to choose a container I will use again. When I use a Ziplock I wash it out and put it away to be used again. I haven't forgotten my cloth and reusable plastic bags to use at the store. IKEA has some for .75 that fold up small enough to fit a couple or three in your purse or one in your pocket. I did forget my car cup when I went for coffee and I felt bad about it, not just slightly remiss. I've been watching the recycle symbols on things I buy to make sure they have a 1 or 2. I will be writing to companies to ask them to make sure they are using those recyclables. I will also request they make large refill sizes for soap and the like. I'd use bar soap but it kills my skin.
This documentary is that eye opening. It will change how you think about everything you consume. Watch it and encourage others to as well, try not to be too obnoxious about it :).
All in all it was an easy film to watch, entertaining as well as informative. Dragged a bit towards the end but not so much I was wondering when it would be over.
04/03/2015
I just wanted to update that we haven't purchased but one new box of plastic storage bags since we watched this, and they are for long term storage, and will used again. We still use plastic trash bags, as we don't see any way to do away with them and keep sanitary.
On a side note, since we have been using reusable containers our crisper and our meat keeper are much cleaner, and our produce keeps longer, our stuff in the freezer keeps better. So not only does using single use bags hurt the environment, they cost you more money, as your food doesn't last as long.
Thanks for the documentary. Good stuff. Review Title: If you watch just one documentary this year... or next... or ever. Rating: 5.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Review Date: 2016/08/19 Average Rating: 3.5 Product Details: {'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['---'], 'Studio': ['Unavailable']} Review Text: This is nothing more than a shameless plug for this guys bottled hot sauce, he goes so far as to spell the website for you so you can go and get it, and he says of the recipe he is making: "this will be good but mine is better". He does make a hot sauce of sorts, nothing you can't find a recipe for anywhere. It's not fermented which is what we were looking for, this belongs on YouTube (maybe, the opening 'music' is loud and annoying), not on Amazon for sale. We've requested our money back, and it should be double or even triple for the time we wasted. Too bad there aren't negative numbers. Review Title: Nothing to see here Rating: 1.0 --------------------------------------------------

Review Title: Nothing to see here Rating: 1.0 -------------------------------------------------- Structure your response as: SUMMARY: [Final synthesis of preferences and patterns]
raw_response:
SUMMARY:
The purchase history reveals a discerning viewer with a clear aversion to gratuitous violence in media, as evidenced by a low rating for a film that did not meet expectations of a light-hearted comedy. Despite this, they appreciate strong performances and well-crafted narratives, as shown by high ratings for works deemed engaging and thought-provoking. 

A recurring theme is a preference for content that encourages environmental awareness and personal growth, illustrated by a glowing review for a documentary that led to significant lifestyle changes. This suggests the individual values educational and transformative experiences, seeking media that resonates beyond entertainment.

Quality is evidently prioritized, as reflected in the tendency to rate meaningful and impactful content highly, while expressing disappointment with poorly made products or those perceived as scams. There’s also a hint of price sensitivity, particularly when disappointing purchases lead to requests for refunds.

Overall, the core preferences suggest this individual enjoys quality storytelling that is either entertaining or socially enlightening, while rejecting content that feels exploitative or fails to deliver genuine value. They are also conscious of the environmental impact of their consumption choices.

target_interaction.title: Not what it appears to be
target_interaction.text: Found with a search for old country music as my 92 yr old Mom likes it, but the description is misleading, starts off with a 45 minute sermon and no music. When we finally got to the music, she and I didn't recognize any of the songs, seemed like they were written for the video. Look elsewhere for old gospel and country songs.
